School of Chemical Engineering University of Adelaide Adelaide SA 5005 Australia 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Ammonia is a vital emerging energy carrier and storage medium in the future hydrogen economy, even presenting relevant advantages compared with methanol due to the higher hydrogen content (17.6 wt% for ammonia versus 12.5 wt% for methanol). The rapidly growing demand for ammonia is still dependent on the conventional high-temperature and high-pressure Haber–Bosch process, which can deliver a conversion rate of about 10%–15%. However, the overall process requires a large amount of fossil fuels, resulting in serious environmental problems. Alternatively, electrochemical routes show the potential to greatly reduce the energy consumption, including sustainable energy sources and simplify the reactor design. Electrolytes perform as indispensable reaction medium during electrochemical processes, which can be further classified into solid oxide electrolytes, molten salt electrolytes, polymer electrolytes, and liquid electrolytes. In this review, recent developments and advances of the electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis catalyzed by a series of functional materials on the basis of aforementioned electrolytes have been summarized and discussed, along with the presentation and evaluation of catalyst preparation, reaction parameters and equipment. Graphical abstract Recent developments of various electrolytes along with the corresponding electrocatalysts in electrochemical N2 reduction at different temperatures are presented and discussed in this review article. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalysis Functional material Ammonia synthesis Electrolyte 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is a unique pungent gas with a lighter density compared with air at room temperature and atmospheric pressure and can be widely used in the fields of textile industry, plastic, energy conversion and fertilizer production, making it one of the most common industrial chemicals produced nowadays [1–3]. Compared with methanol, liquid ammonia, with 17.6 wt% hydrogen, is a very promising emerging energy carrier and storage medium for the future hydrogen economy [4,5]. Obviously, the rapidly growing demand for ammonia has led to a huge consumption with 150 million tons per year as a result of the aforementioned applications. The industrial synthesis process of ammonia simply follows the reaction as shown below: N2 + 3H2↔2NH3 in which the N2 molecule comprises the highly stable NN structure with a considerably large binding energy of 962 kJ•mol−1 [6–9]. Moreover, the N2 gas volume decreases when converted into NH3, and accordingly, at high temperature NN triple binding can be broken and the N2 kinetic energy overcomes the inert synthesis reaction of ammonia. High pressure is used to promote the equilibrium toward the product direction, thus increasing the reaction conversion and reducing the reverse decomposition of NH3 to N2. Based on the above principles, the Haber–Bosch NH3 production technology, relying on Fe-based catalysts, is one of the most popular processes operating at high temperature (350–550 °C) and high pressure (150–350 atm) [6–9]. The process is associated with high energy consumption of about 485 kJ•mol−1 of NH3 and a relatively low equilibrium conversion of 10%–15%. In addition, in order to convert 120 million tons of N2 from the air, the process results in 200 million tons of CO2 emission to provide required H2 from fossil fuels (e.g., natural gas, coal and oil) [10–12]. Alternative environmental-friendly method of biological N2 fixation takes place primarily in microbial organisms with nitrogenases, which catalyze the reduction of H+ and N2 to finally generate H2 and NH3 [13–15]. However, this process is associated with relatively slow reaction rate, which is not compatible with industrial requirements. Therefore, it is urgent to explore energy-saving, environmental-friendly and highly efficient processes for large-scale production of ammonia. Electrocatalytic N2 reduction process is a promising candidate which would save over 20% of the total energy consumption compared to the Haber–Bosch technology. Additionally, the electrochemical reduction can also be powered in conjunction with renewable solar and wind energy, which provides a great potential for commercial applications. Several electrocatalytic routes [16–32] for the ammonia synthesis have been demonstrated in Table 1 , the reaction temperature varies depending on the utilized electrocatalysts and electrolytes. More specifically, in the high-temperature range beyond 500 °C, solid oxide electrolytes, most commonly reported electrolytes so far, are based on proton-conducting perovskites of strontium zirconate [21,33–35] and barium cerate [36–39]. Noble metals such as Ag-Pd are usually used as catalytic electrodes. In the medium-temperature range between 200 and 500 °C, molten salt electrolytes such as LiCl-KCl-Li3N and LiCl-KCl-CsCl alkali-metal halides are the common choice to synthesize ammonia [23,40–44]. Recently, an electrocatalytic cell based on molten hydroxide (NaOH/KOH) electrolyte operated at 200 °C, was reported with porous Ni mixed with high-surface-area nano-Fe2O3 catalysts [24,45]. However, limited reports can be found on the electro-synthesis of ammonia at low temperature (i.e., below 100 °C) or even at room temperature. At this temperature range, the Nafion membrane with a good proton conductivity of 4.5 × 10−2 S•cm−1 at 80 °C was most adopted [25–27,46]. Very recently, intense research has been devoted to identifying special electrocatalysts for ammonia production using liquid electrolytes at room temperature [28–32]. The ammonia electro-reduction reaction with liquid electrolytes allows the room temperature synthesis and hardly involves complex and expensive electrolytes. Therefore, an updated summary is urgent and beneficial for understanding the recent progress of electrocatalytic ammonia production. In this review, we will explore the developments of electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis based on various electrolytes operating at different temperature ranges, with emphasis on new material preparation, ammonia production rates and reaction instruments. 2 Solid oxide electrolytes at high temperature (>500 °C) Solid oxide based cells for N2 reduction can overcome limitations of conventional catalytic reactors, e.g., limited conversion and high energy consumption [16–18]. The typical cell mainly consists of two porous electrodes (i.e., anode and cathode) and a dense solid oxide electrolyte. The solid oxide electrolyte separates the anode from the cathode, allows ion transport of either protons or oxide ions and serves as a barrier to gas diffusion [47,48]. The typical schematics of solid oxide based cells using proton conducting electrolytes for N2 reduction are shown in Fig. 1 . The solid oxide can be a perovskite-type, pyrochlore-type or fluorite-type oxide. Fig. 2 (a) represents the typical structure of a perovskite-type oxide (barium cerate-based oxides, BaCeO3), which can be generally expressed as ABO3, where the A site is occupied by a rare earth cation and the B site is occupied by a transition metal [49], such as strontium zirconate (SrZrO3 or SrCeO3), barium cerate (BaCeO3) and Lanthanum gallate (LaGaO3). These compound formulas can also be expressed as AB1− x M x O3− δ , while M is a divalent cation (Ca2+) or a trivalent cation (Y3+, Gd3+, Yb3+, Nd3+, Sm3+, etc.), and δ is the oxygen deficiency in the oxide lattice [48–52]. All the above solid state electrolytes display high proton conductivity in hydrogen-containing atmosphere and at elevated temperature. Fig. 2(b) displays a typical pyrochlore-type oxide structure with a general formula of A2B2O7 comprising two types of cations (A3+ and B4+). When the cation radius ratio, r(A3+)/r(B4+), is larger than 1.22, a pyrochlore structure (e.g., La2Zr2O7) can be obtained; otherwise, a fluorite structure (e.g., La2Ce2O7) can be formed. The pyrochlore structure can be turned into fluorite structure at high temperature (1377–2227 °C) [53–55]. Pyrochlore materials feature fast ionic conduction due to the presence of many non-occupied sites [56–58], while protonic conduction occurs only under hydrogen-containing atmosphere and at high temperature [59,60]. The typical fluorite structure with oxygen ion-conducting properties is given in Fig. 2(c). The general formula of fluorite oxide can be presented as AO2, in which A is a tetravalent cation with a large ion radius (Ce4+, U4+, Th4+, etc.) [49]. SrCeO3 is proton-conducting perovskite under hydrogen containing atmosphere and high temperature (500–1000 °C) [21,33–35,61,62]. The working principle of the solid oxide system for N2 reduction is as follows: two metal electrodes are placed on both sides of the proton conductor; gaseous Η2 is flown over the anode and converted into H+; protons are transported to the cathode, where the half-cell reaction of N2 and H+ will take place to produce ammonia. Since then, different kinds of proton conducting ceramics have been synthesized through doping aliovalent cations. Marnellos and Stoukides [21] prepared a novel electrolyte material made of SrCe0.95Yb0.05O3 to replace the ammonia synthesis route developed by Panagos et al. [62]. This cell used palladium (Pd) catalytic electrode, manifesting convert ratio of more than 78% from the supplied protons to ammonia. A further step can be implemented to achieve the convert ratio nearly 80% based on double- and single-chamber cells operated at 570–750 °C and atmospheric pressure [33,63]. Different from early reports, Skodra and Stoukides [35] reported the electrocatalytic synthesis of ammonia from steam and nitrogen, meaning that the further purification of molecular hydrogen can be possibly omitted due to the steam. As shown in Fig. 3 , the electrochemical cell employed SrCe0.95Yb0.05O3 as the proton conducting solid electrolyte, with the Ru-based and Pd catalysts as the cathode and anode, respectively. Steam was reduced to O2 and H+ by electrolysis, while H+ is transported to cathode through a proton conductor disk, to react with nitrogen and form ammonia. Notably, during the whole reaction process, only nitrogen needed to be purified. Although ammonia was successfully formed at 450–700 °C, a low conversion rate of nitrogen or steam into ammonia was observed due to the poor conductivity of the working electrode. Doped barium cerate materials with the formula of BaCe1− x M x O3− δ exhibit appreciable proton conductivity, especially for Gd-doped barium cerate [36–39,64–69] that features the highest electrical conductivity at high temperature (>800 °C). A single phase perovskite-type complex oxide (BaCe0.8Gd0.2O3− δ ) was synthesized with relative density exceeding 90% following the citrate method at 1300 °C for 10 h [65]. When employed as the solid oxide electrolyte at atmospheric pressure, BaCe0.8Gd0.2O3− δ can deliver an ammonia production rate of 3.1 × 10−9 mol•s−1•cm−2 at 480 °C. Further, a wet chemical microemulsion method was developed to decrease the sintering temperature [67], allowing to prepare BaCe1− x Gd x O3− δ (0.05 ≤ x ≤ 0.20) ceramic powders at the temperature of 1500 °C, and the highest protonic conductivity (1.4 × 10−2 S•cm−1) was achieved at x = 0.15 and 600 °C. The BaCe0.85Gd0.15O3− δ film was successfully assembled into an ammonia electrolytic cell and the NH3 formation rate was 4.6 × 10−9 mol•s−1•cm−2 at 480 °C with an imposed direct current of 1.5 mA. Other solid oxide electrolytes for ammonia electro-reduction reaction include perovskite-type lanthanum gallate (LaGaO3)-based electrolytes [70–72], pyrochlore-type solid oxide electrolytes [53,73], fluorite-type solid oxide electrolytes [74,75] and complex perovskite-type solid oxide electrolytes [76–80]. The ammonia production rates and reaction temperatures of some typical solid oxide electrolytes are summarized in Table 2 . Although the solid oxide electrolytes display high protonic conductivity over 500 °C, few materials with high protonic conductivity are reported till now. This is because the specific solid oxide materials with high protonic conductivity at the temperature range of 200–500 °C normally exhibit low catalytic activity. Therefore, the development of materials with high Faradaic efficiency and fast ammonia production rate are important at the medium temperature range of 200–500 °C. 3 Molten salt electrolytes at medium temperature range of 200–500 °C Among electrochemical platforms for ammonia synthesis, molten salt electrolytes have drawn continuous attention owing to their high ionic conductivity and relatively mild reaction conditions. Licht et al. [24,81] found a new high-surface-area nano-Fe2O3 electrode material that was capable of providing high NH3 generation rate from water or steam at 200 °C using the molten hydroxide (NaOH/KOH) electrolyte (Fig. 4 a). Compared with conventional micro-Fe2O3 particles, nano-Fe2O3 showed a higher current efficiency of 35% (Fig. 4b) owing to its high surface area and abundant active sites. The corresponding ammonia synthesis mechanism was proposed as follows: (i) the electrochemical reduction of water to hydrogen at the cathode, followed by (ii) the diffusion of hydrogen from the cathode to the nano-Fe2O3 surface, and finally (iii) the reaction between hydrogen with the adsorbed nitrogen to yield ammonia. Another possible mechanism was the electrochemical reduction of nitrogen and steam at the surface of the nano-Fe2O3 following the electron transmission process from the Ni cathode to the electrolyte-suspended nano-Fe2O3. Moreover, in a self-pressurizing solar thermal water cell, a low energy electrolysis path was also achieved as shown in Fig. 5 (a) [45]. The solar generated high pressure of the reactant gas phase equilibrates with gas or molten phase reactants to decrease the electrochemical potential required for endothermic electrolyses. Sunlight provides the energy to evaporate a reactant in a constrained volume, driving the reactant to high pressure. The sunlight also provides higher temperature, which further decreases the electrolysis splitting energy. Solar thermal energy here provides an efficient energy source and mechanism to maintain a high reactant pressure. The conversion efficiency exceeding 65% was obtained for the absorbed solar thermal energy which provided an efficient energy source to maintain a high reactant pressure. Further experiments in a 200 °C molten hydroxide (NaOH/KOH) electrolyte (Fig. 5b) indicated that the Faraday efficiency of the synthesized ammonia (η NH3) increased with a decreasing current density of 20 mA•cm−2, affording the ammonia production rate of 1.6 × 10−8 mol•cm−2•s−1. Electrolytic cells with other molten salt electrolytes were also built for ammonia synthesis to exploit their high ionic conductivity, thermodynamic stability, wide electrochemical window and low vapor pressure [82,83]. The Murakami group [23,41–44] attempted to use various hydrogen sources to produce ammonia at ambient pressure according to the underlying principles (Fig. 6 a). The electrolyte containing molten alkali-metal halides such as LiCl-KCl-Li3N and LiCl-KCl-CsCl. Nitrogen gas was sent to the porous cathode, providing a continuous supply of nitride ions through the reduction of N2 into N3−. Meanwhile, hydrogen gas was purged to the porous anode or a hydrogen permeable membrane. Consequently ammonia was electrochemically produced from the reaction of H2 and N3−. Nonetheless, alkali-metal halide systems remain a lab-scale technology. The most limiting factor of N2 reduction is the extremely strong triple NN bond, which results in a sluggish reaction kinetics [84]. Kim et al. [85] evaluated the catalytic activity of nano-Fe2O3 and CoFe2O4 suspended in a molten LiCl-KCl-CsCl electrolyte (Fig. 6b) at 327 °C. The ammonia production rate for nano-CoFe2O4 and Fe2O3 were 1.8 × 10−10 and 3.0 × 10−10 mol•s−1•cm−2, respectively. Fig. 6(c) illustrates the schematic mechanism of ammonia synthesis based on reaction sites on the working electrodes in the presence and absence of nano-catalysts. For the Ni electrode without nanocatalysts, there was only one available type of active sites on Ni surface. After suspending the nanocatalysts in molten chloride, two additional active sites for the catalytic reactions could be realized, namely, one at the nanoparticle surface and the other at the electrode/nanoparticle junction. Accordingly, high catalytic activity and electrical conductivity were achieved with the help of nanocatalyst [86]. Table 3 shows the ammonia production rate and reaction temperature of molten salt electrolytes. It can be seen that high ionic conductivity of salt electrolytes fills in the blanks of materials at 200–500 °C. However, because there is still problem of reducing the back decomposition of NH3 to N2 in the electrochemical cell involving molten salt electrolytes, it is necessary to further optimize the operation temperature to increase the ammonia production efficiency. 4 Polymer-type electrolytes at low temperature (<100 °C) According to the above sections, ammonia has been extensively synthesized using high-temperature solid state oxide electrolytes with sufficient efficiency. In contrast, low-temperature synthesis could avoid the partial ammonia decomposition at high temperature, as the overall reaction is exothermic. Liu and coworkers [25,26,87,88] developed new cathode catalysts based on Sm1.5Sr0.5MO4 (M=Ni, Co, Fe), SmFe0.7Cu0.3− x Ni x O3 (x = 0–0.3) and SmBaCuMO5+ δ (M=Fe, Co, Ni) for ammonia synthesis at atmospheric pressure and low temperature with Nafion used as proton solid electrolyte. Impressively, the SmFe0.7Cu0.1Ni0.2O3 catalyst showed the record-high ammonia production rate of 1.1 × 10−8 mol•s−1•cm−2 at 80 °C. Further, the same group [88,89] tried to replace expensive Nafion membrane with a sulfonated polysulfone proton exchange membrane, which resulted in a high rate for the evolution of ammonia (6.5 × 10−9 mol•s−1•cm−2 at 80 °C) by combining the Sm0.5Sr0.5CoO3− δ (SSC) or Ni-Ce0.8Sm0.2O2− δ (Ni-SDC) cathode and the Ni/SDC anode. Unfortunately, the chemical reaction between active metal Ni and acidic Nafion forming Ni2+ led to sharp decrease of the proton conductivity. Recently artificial ammonia synthesis directly from air and water at ambient temperature and pressure was reported [46]. A maximum ammonia production rate of 1.1 × 10−9 mol•s−1•cm−2 was achieved at 1.6 V using a solid state electrolyte of mixed NH4+/H+ conducting Nafion polymer membrane. This work provides a new route for the mass production of ammonia under mild conditions. Further introducing Li+ into above mixed conducting membrane could lead to the formation of H+/Li+/NH4+ conducting Nafion membrane [27], in which Li+ ions are capable of reducing the ammonia formation due to the blocking effect of Li+ on the transferred protons, thus resulting in relatively lower current at high applied voltage. Therefore, the highest ammonia formation rate ever reported of 9.37 × 10−10 mol•s−1•cm−2 was obtained at the temperature of 80 °C. In this section, it can be seen that a relatively high temperature of 80 °C is still needed for the electrolytic cells with polymer-type electrolytes, which may also be confronted with the problem of back decomposition of NH3 to N2, low ammonia formation rate, and inferior stability. Further lowering down the operating temperature is still urgent to access the high ammonia production efficiency. 5 Liquid electrolytes at room temperature Ammonia electro-reduction reaction with liquid electrolytes is one of the most realistic ways at present to conduct the ammonia production under ambient conditions. It can avoid drawbacks from the use of solid oxide, molten salt and polymer electrolytes involving energy-consuming high temperature as well as complex and expensive materials. Note that the preparation of special electrocatalysts with readily controllable structures [28–31] gradually becomes a new field of research due to major recent advances. Bao et al. [28] recently reported the use of tetrahexahedral gold nanorods as a heterogeneous electrocatalyst for the electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Fig. 7 (a) shows that tetrahexahedral gold nanorods were enclosed by the (730) stepped facet which was composed of (210) and (310) sub-facets. A three-electrode configuration was employed in a two-compartment cell separated by a Nafion 211 membrane with 0.1 M KOH solution (Fig. 7b). The anodic reaction is the O2 evolution while the cathode reaction corresponds to the ammonia formation catalyzed by the gold nanorods. The achieved ammonia production rate was 1.7 µg•h−1•cm−2 with a high Faraday efficiency up to 4.02% at −0.2 V. The ammonia synthesis mechanism can be depicted as follows. Firstly, the N2 molecule is adsorbed weakly on the Au stepped facets forming Au−N bonds (Fig. 7c); then the NN triple bond is broken and a more stable N−H bond is formed with the activated H from H2O by electrolysis; finally N2 hydrogenation is achieved through the addition of H atoms from the electrolyte and electrons from the electrode surface. Indeed, the particle size of active Au electrocatalysts can influence the reaction efficiency deeply. In order to investigate the effect of the Au particle size during electrochemical N2 reduction, three Au/TiO2 catalysts were fabricated: a tannic acid (TA)-reduced Au/TiO2 (Fig. 8 a), a NaBH4-reduced Au/TiO2 (Fig. 8b) and a photo-reduced Au/TiO2 (Fig. 8c) [29]. Their electrocatalytic N2 reduction performance was investigated in acid media with the three-electrode setup. The ammonia production rate of each electrocatalytic Au/TiO2 system showed that sub-nanometer TA-reduced Au clusters afforded the highest electrocatalytic activity with a production rate of 21.4 µg•h−1•mg−1 (Fig. 8d). Fig. 8(e) indicates the possible N2 reduction reaction mechanism based on Au/TiO2. Firstly, the electro-neutral N2 molecule is absorbed by the partially positively-charged Au active centers; the positively charged H+ cations in the electrolyte form stable N−H bond other than participate in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER); subsequently, NN triple bonds are broken to form more stable N−H bonds thanks to activated H coming from the electrolysis of H2O; finally, N2 hydrogenation occurs through the addition of two additional H atoms and one electron. When using strong alkali (KOH or NaOH) solutions as electrolytes for the ammonia synthesis with N2 sourced from the air, the efficiency is always limited because the CO2 present in the air may react with strong alkali to form carbonates. In order to overcome this problem, Chen et al. [30] utilized a less concentrated KHCO3 as the cathode half-cell electrolyte where the reduction of N2 to NH3 occurred (Fig. 9 ). This apparatus can provide a high ammonia formation rate of 2.2 × 10−3 g•h−1•m−2 with ammonia Faraday efficiency of 0.02% at 20 °C and atmospheric pressure. The catalyst used was the non-noble metal iron oxide nanoparticles supported on conductive carbon nanotubes that form the gas diffusion layer. In the meanwhile, this electrocatalyst diffusion layer was also connected to Nafion membrane. This non-conventional catalyst-layer-membrane structure was defined as a membrane-electrode assembly which separated the two parts of the reaction cell. Very recently, a novel electrocatalyst system was developed by incorporating Li+ into poly(N-ethyl-benzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic diimide) (PEBCD) (Fig. 10 a and b) [31], which was able to increase the N2 electro-reduction reaction activity under ambient conditions with ammonia production rate up to 9.3 × 10−4 mol•h−1•m−2 and a Faradaic efficiency of 2.58% using 0.5 M Li2SO4 aqueous solution (Fig. 10c). Further investigations indicated that the side HER reaction was inhibited by the synergistic effect of Li+ ions and O atoms in the PEBCD matrix. In the “[O–Li+]•N2 H x ” alternating hydrogenation mode (Fig. 10d), a higher selectivity versus the ammonia electro-reduction reaction was achieved, providing a new pathway for the synthesis of ammonia from H2O and N2 at ambient conditions. Other kinds of electrolytes have also been used for ammonia electro-reduction reaction, including sulfuric acid [32], organic electrolytes of tetrahydrofuran [90], methanol [91], 2-propanol [92] and ethylenediamine [93]. The purpose of selecting electrolytes is to increase the N2 solubility, thereby improving the ammonia production rate. Moreover, the surface properties and electronic structures of electrocatalyts are also important factors for suppressing HER in the aqueous systems where the N2 electro-reduction reaction occurs under ambient conditions. 6 Conclusions Recent advances of the electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis based on solid oxide, molten salt, polymer and liquid electrolytes were discussed, along with the development of new types of electrocatalysts under various reaction conditions. Compared with conventional Haber–Bosch process, the electrochemical routes show the potential to greatly reduce the energy consumption, to involve sustainable energy sources and to simplify the reactor design. Based on the review, it is found that the electrochemical ammonia production rate is usually distributed in the region of 10−13–10−8 mol•s−1•cm−2, while the maximum rate of around 1.1 × 10−8 mol•s−1•cm−2, has been derived from the electrochemical ammonia cell utilizing the Nafion membrane at 80 °C. However, the electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis is still under experiment stage, huge challenges are still faced such as the lack of the solid oxide electrolyte materials in the temperature range of 200–500 °C, reverse decomposition of NH3 to N2 for the electrochemical cell involving molten salt and polymer electrolytes, as well as limited selection of liquid electrolytes for enhancing the N2 solubility and improving the ammonia production rate. Promisingly, the advanced electrocatalysts involved system using liquid electrolytes affords an attractive pathway for ammonia production due to its operation condition at room temperature, cost-effective electrolytes and easily accessed catalysts. Soc. 163 2016 F1523 F1526 Xinghua Guo is an associate professor of Liaoning University, China. He received his Ph.D. degree from Harbin Institute of Technology in 2009 and became an associate professor in 2014 at Institute Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Science. From 2017, he began to work in Liaoning University. He has coauthored more than 30 peer-reviewed scientific papers, and holds 8 patents. His research interests focus on electrochemical reduction ammonia for energy conversion, electrode preparation for lithium battery, and corrosion protection of light metal alloy. Yunpei Zhu received his Ph.D. degree in Chemistry from Nankai University and his research interests relate to the design and development of functional nanostructured materials for sustainable energy and environment like electrocatalysis, metal-air batteries, Li-ion batteries, photocatalysis and selective adsorption and separation. Dr. Zhu also acts as an editor of MAYFEB Journal of Energy. Tianyi Ma received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from Nankai University, Dr. Ma worked as a postdoctoral research fellow from 2013 to 2014 in School of Chemical Engineering, University of Adelaide. Then he was awarded Australian Research Council (ARC) Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DECRA), and continued research on the rational design, synthesis and characterization of nanostructured materials composed of a large variety of components from carbons, metals, metal oxides, organic polymers to metal-organic frameworks. He has especially aimed at the energy and environment related applications of these nanostructured materials including catalysis, adsorption and separation, and energy conversion and storage. His recent effort is focused on metal-N2 and metal-CO2 batteries involving N2 fixation and CO2 reduction processes.

coredata.dc:description: Ammonia is a vital emerging energy carrier and storage medium in the future hydrogen economy, even presenting relevant advantages compared with methanol due to the higher hydrogen content (17.6 wt% for ammonia versus 12.5 wt% for methanol). The rapidly growing demand for ammonia is still dependent on the conventional high-temperature and high-pressure Haber–Bosch process, which can deliver a conversion rate of about 10%–15%. However, the overall process requires a large amount of fossil fuels, resulting in serious environmental problems. Alternatively, electrochemical routes show the potential to greatly reduce the energy consumption, including sustainable energy sources and simplify the reactor design. Electrolytes perform as indispensable reaction medium during electrochemical processes, which can be further classified into solid oxide electrolytes, molten salt electrolytes, polymer electrolytes, and liquid electrolytes. In this review, recent developments and advances of the electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis catalyzed by a series of functional materials on the basis of aforementioned electrolytes have been summarized and discussed, along with the presentation and evaluation of catalyst preparation, reaction parameters and equipment.
